questions.prompt: In a context-free grammar, what appears on the left side of a production?
questions.explanation: CFG productions have exactly one non-terminal on the left side, distinguishing them from unrestricted grammars.

options: A grammar with no valid derivations
A grammar that can produce multiple parse trees for some input
questions.explanation: An ambiguous grammar allows more than one parse tree (derivation) for the same input string.

questions.prompt: What is the start symbol in a grammar?
options: The non-terminal from which all derivations begin
Any symbol can be the start
questions.explanation: The start symbol is the designated non-terminal from which all valid derivations must begin.

options: Starting from the left of the input
questions.explanation: A leftmost derivation always expands the leftmost non-terminal at each step.

questions.prompt: What is the yield of a parse tree?
options: The string of terminals at the leaves read left to right
questions.explanation: The yield is the string formed by concatenating the leaves (terminals) from left to right.

questions.prompt: What is the main challenge with left-recursive grammars in top-down parsing?
questions.explanation: Left recursion causes recursive descent parsers to loop infinitely without consuming input.

questions.prompt: What is the FIRST set of a grammar symbol?
options: The first production for that symbol
The set of terminals that can begin strings derived from it
The first symbol in each production
questions.explanation: FIRST(X) is the set of terminals that can appear as the first symbol of any string derived from X.

questions.prompt: When is epsilon (ε) in the FIRST set of a non-terminal?
options: When it can derive the empty string
When it appears in a production
When it is the start symbol
questions.explanation: ε ∈ FIRST(A) if A can derive the empty string (A ⇒* ε).

questions.prompt: What is the FOLLOW set used for in LL parsing?
options: Deciding which production to use when FIRST sets overlap or contain ε
questions.explanation: FOLLOW sets help choose productions when the current non-terminal can derive ε.
LL(1): scan Left-to-right, produce Leftmost derivation, using 1 token of lookahead.

questions.prompt: What are the two main actions in shift-reduce parsing?
questions.explanation: Shift pushes input onto the stack; reduce replaces a production's RHS with its LHS.

questions.prompt: What is a handle in bottom-up parsing?
options: A string matching a production's RHS that should be reduced
questions.explanation: A handle is a substring matching a production body that, when reduced, leads to a valid parse.

options: Parser cannot decide between shifting and reducing
questions.explanation: A shift-reduce conflict occurs when the parser cannot decide whether to shift the next token or reduce the current handle.

questions.prompt: Which is more powerful: LL(1) or LR(1)?
questions.explanation: LR(1) parsers can handle a strictly larger class of grammars than LL(1) parsers.

questions.prompt: What tool generates LALR parsers from grammar specifications?
questions.explanation: Yacc (and GNU bison) generate LALR(1) parsers from grammar specifications.
